question: [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/node/local_testnet/ready_server.rs] [Struct: ReadyServerArgs] [Port exhaustion] Can an attacker set ready_server_listen_port to privileged ports (<1024) or already-in-use ports causing the ready server to fail startup and preventing testnet initialization? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/node/local_testnet/ready_server.rs] [Struct: ReadyServerArgs] [Port collision] Does the default port 8070 conflict with other services in the localnet, and can an attacker exploit port binding races to hijack the ready server endpoint? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/node/local_testnet/ready_server.rs] [Function: run_ready_server()] [Network binding vulnerability] Can an attacker manipulate the bind_to Ipv4Addr parameter to bind the server to a public interface (0.0.0.0) instead of localhost, exposing internal health status to external attackers? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/node/local_testnet/ready_server.rs] [Function: run_ready_server()] [Socket binding race] Is there a race condition between checking port availability and binding to SocketAddrV4 that could allow an attacker to bind to the same port first, causing denial of service? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/node/local_testnet/ready_server.rs] [Struct: ReadyServerManager] [Health checker injection] Can an attacker inject malicious HealthChecker instances into the health_checkers HashSet during construction, causing the server to check attacker-controlled endpoints? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/node/local_testnet/ready_server.rs] [Function: new()] [Unvalidated health checkers] Does new() validate that health_checkers contains only legitimate local testnet services, or can an attacker pass arbitrary URLs pointing to external malicious servers? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/node/local_testnet/ready_server.rs] [Struct: HealthCheckers] [State mutation] Since HealthCheckers is Clone and contains a HashSet, can concurrent cloning and modification lead to race conditions where health checkers are added/removed during checks? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/node/local_testnet/ready_server.rs] [Function: root()] [Health checker manipulation] Can an attacker modify the health_checkers HashSet after server startup but before health checks execute, causing incorrect ready status reporting? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/node/local_testnet/ready_server.rs] [Function: root()] [Timeout DoS] The timeout is hardcoded to 3 seconds per health checker - can an attacker add hundreds of slow-responding health checkers to cause the root handler to take minutes to respond, leading to API timeout DoS? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/node/local_testnet/ready_server.rs] [Function: root()] [Resource exhaustion] Does the root() handler have any limit on concurrent health check operations? Can an attacker send multiple simultaneous requests causing unbounded parallel health checks and CPU/memory exhaustion? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/node/local_testnet/ready_server.rs] [Function: root()] [Timeout bypass] If health_checker.check() hangs indefinitely despite the 3-second timeout, can this cause goroutine/task leaks accumulating over multiple requests and eventually crashing the server? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/node/local_testnet/ready_server.rs] [Function: root()] [Sequential checking] Since health checks are done sequentially in a for loop, can an attacker exploit this to cause O(n*3s) response times where n is number of checkers, making the API unusable? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/node/local_testnet/ready_server.rs] [Function: root()] [Timeout accumulation] With N health checkers each taking 3 seconds on timeout, can total response time reach 3*N seconds, causing upstream timeouts and cascading failures in dependent services? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/node/local_testnet/ready_server.rs] [Function: root()] [Race condition on vectors] The ready and not_ready vectors are built without synchronization - can concurrent requests to root() cause data races if the health_checkers set is modified during iteration? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/node/local_testnet/ready_server.rs] [Struct: ReadyServerManager] [Clone safety] ReadyServerManager derives Clone - can concurrent clones of health_checkers HashSet lead to use-after-free or double-free vulnerabilities if underlying HealthChecker instances are not thread-safe? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/node/local_testnet/ready_server.rs] [Function: root()] [Concurrent health checks] If multiple HTTP requests hit root() simultaneously, are health checks properly isolated or can they interfere with each other's network connections leading to false negatives? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/node/local_testnet/ready_server.rs] [Function: run_ready_server()] [Server shutdown race] Is there a race condition between server startup and shutdown where the server could exit unexpectedly without proper cleanup of open health check connections? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/node/local_testnet/ready_server.rs] [Function: root()] [Service enumeration] Does the ReadyData response expose all internal service names and endpoints through the ready/not_ready vectors, allowing attackers to map the internal network topology? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/node/local_testnet/ready_server.rs] [Struct: ReadyData] [Information leakage] Since ReadyData serializes HealthChecker instances which contain URLs and connection strings, can this leak sensitive database credentials, API keys, or internal IP addresses? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/node/local_testnet/ready_server.rs] [Function: root()] [Error message leakage] When health checks fail, are detailed error messages from health_checker.check() exposed in the response, potentially revealing version information, stack traces, or system paths? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/node/local_testnet/ready_server.rs] [Function: root()] [Timing attack] Can an attacker use response timing differences to determine which specific services are down, enabling targeted attacks on the weakest components? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/node/local_testnet/ready_server.rs] [Function: run_ready_server()] [Unexpected exit error] Line 96 returns an error if the server exits unexpectedly - but is this error properly propagated and handled, or does it silently fail leaving the testnet in an inconsistent state? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/node/local_testnet/ready_server.rs] [Function: root()] [Panic on serialization] If Json(ReadyData) serialization panics due to malformed HealthChecker data, can this crash the entire ready server and prevent all health checks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/node/local_testnet/ready_server.rs] [Function: root()] [Unhandled timeout errors] The timeout match uses wildcard pattern for errors - does this silently ignore critical errors like network failures, making services appear not_ready when they're actually unreachable? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/node/local_testnet/ready_server.rs] [Function: root()] [Error swallowing] By catching all errors with _ pattern, can critical failures like out-of-memory or stack overflow be hidden, causing mysterious service outages? (Medium)
